Robot module¶

Generic definition of a robot.

Currently subclasses from the iRobotCreate class to allow for physical control of an iRobot Create base (if the Robot class is configured to control hardware) but could be subclassed to use other physical hardware in the future.

A robot has a planner that allows it to select goals and a map to keep track of other robots, feasible regions to which it can move, an occupancy grid representation of the world, and role-specific information (such as a probability layer for the rop robot to keep track of where robber robots may be).

class Robot(name, pose=[0, 0.5, 0], map_name='fleming', role='robber', status=['on the run', 'without a goal'], planner_type='simple', consider_others=False, control_hardware=False, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: cops_and_robots.robo_tools.iRobot_create.iRobotCreate

Class definition for the generic robot object.

Parameters:
  • name (str) – The robot’s name.
  • pose (array_like, optional) – The robot’s initial [x, y, theta] in [m,m,degrees] (defaults to [0, 0.5, 0]).
  • map_name (str, optional) – The name of the map (defaults to ‘fleming’).
  • role ({‘robber’,’cop’}, optional) – The robot’s role in the cops and robbers game.
  • status (two-element list of strings, optional) –

    The robot’s initial mission status and movement status. Cops and robbers share possible movement statuses, but their mission statuses

    differ entirely. Defaults to [‘on the run’, ‘without a goal’].
  • planner_type ({‘simple’, ‘particle’, ‘MAP’}, optional) – The robot’s type of planner.
  • consider_others (bool, optional) – Whether this robot generates other robot models (e.g. the primary cop will imagine other robots moving around.) Defaults to false.
  • control_hardware (bool, optional) – Whether this robot controls physical hardware. Defaults to false.
  • **kwargs –

    Arguments passed to the MapObj attribute.
all_robots¶

dict

A dictionary of all robot names (as the key) and their respective roles (as the value).

movement_statuses¶

{‘stuck’,’at goal’,’near goal’,’on goal path’,

‘rotating’,’without a goal’} The possible movement statuses of any robot, where:

  • stuck means the robot hasn’t moved recently;
  • at goal means the robot has reached its goal pose;
  • near goal means the robot has reached its goal pose in

cartesian distance, but has not rotated to the final pose; * on goal path means the robot is translating along the goal path; * rotating means the robot is rotating to align itself with the next path segment; * without a goal means the robot has no movement goal.

all_robots = {'Roy': 'robber', 'Deckard': 'cop', 'Leon': 'robber'}
has_new_goal()[source]¶

Check if the robot received a new goal from the planner.

Returns:True if the robot has a new goal, false otherwise.
Return type:bool
is_at_goal()[source]¶

Check if the robot is near its goal in both distance and rotation.

Once the robot is near its goal, it rotates towards the final goal pose. Once it reaches this goal pose (within some predetermined rotation allowance), it is deemed to be at its goal.

Returns:True if the robot is at its goal, false otherwise.
Return type:bool
is_near_goal()[source]¶

Check if the robot is near its goal (in distance, not rotation).

The robot will only rotate to its final goal pose after it no longer needs to translate to be close enough to its goal point. ‘Close enough’ is given by a predetermined distance allowance.

Returns:True if the robot is near its goal, false otherwise.
Return type:bool
is_on_path()[source]¶

Check if the robot is on the correct path.

The robot will first rotate to the correct angle before translating towards its goal.

Returns:True if the robot is pointing along the goal path, false otherwise.
Return type:bool
is_stuck()[source]¶

Check if the robot has not moved significantly.

Evaluated overover some n time steps. If the robot has not existed for n time steps, it is assumed to not be stuck.

make_others()[source]¶

Generate robot objects for all other robots.

Create personal belief (not necessarily true!) of other robots, largely regarding their map positions. Their positions are known to the ‘self’ robot, but this function will be expanded in the future to include registration between robots: i.e., optional pose and information sharing instead of predetermined sharing.

movement_statuses = ['stuck', 'at goal', 'near goal', 'on goal path', 'rotating', 'without a goal']

Rotate the robot about its centroid towards a goal angle.

Parameters:theta (float, optional) – The goal angle in degrees for the robot to attempt to rotate towards. Defaults to the robot’s current goal pose angle.
translate_towards_goal(path=None)[source]¶

Move the robot’s x,y positions towards a goal point.

Parameters:
  • path (LineString, optional) – a line representing the path to the goal.
  • path – A movement path represented as a Shapely LineString.Defaults to the robot’s current path.
update(i=0)[source]¶

Update all primary functionality of the robot.

This includes planning and movement for both cops and robbers, as well as sensing and map animations for cops.

Parameters:i (int, optional) – The current animation frame. Default is 0 for non-animated robots.
Returns:None if the robot does not generate an animation packet, or a tuple of all animation parameters otherwise.
Return type:tuple or None
update_movement_status()[source]¶

Define the robot’s current movement status.

The robot can be:
  1. stuck (hasn’t moved recently)
  2. at goal (reached its goal pose)
  3. near goal (x and y are close to goal pose, but not theta)
  4. on goal path (translating along its goal path)
  5. rotating (turning to align with path segment)
  6. without a goal (in need of a goal pose and path)
